Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: Several other volunteers can easily cover the first part of the shift if someone shows up a little late.
Story: Every Sunday evening, I call my parents. It’s a ritual—my mom waits for my voice, my dad always asks about my week. Tonight, as I’m about to dial, my phone buzzes with a reminder: my volunteer shift at the shelter starts in fifteen minutes. I’m supposed to be there on time, but I know the others can handle things if I’m a bit late. Still, I promised myself I’d be reliable, not just another name on the schedule. My parents, though, expect this call. They worry if I skip it, and I can already picture my mom’s anxious texts if I don’t check in. I stare at the clock, feeling the pressure build. If I call home, I’ll be late to the shelter. If I rush out now, I’ll break my parents’ trust. My chest tightens as I weigh the disappointment I might cause either way, torn between being a good son and a dependable volunteer.
